subject: Re: Call of Cthulhu: Typo Report: ¶6, ¶7; more name-dot confusion
msgSnippet: There are a few cases, especially after vowels, where an extra Utter is currently used to show that an L is syllabic. Utter is used extensively to show
messageBody:
There are a few cases, especially after vowels, where an extra Utter is currently used to show that an L is syllabic. Utter is used extensively to show syllabic /n/ as well. While the syllabics would not be vital, they would reduce ambiguity further.

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Nathan Sharfi <bonusfrogs@...> wrote:
>
> On May 18, 2013, at 1:53 PM, Timothy <tim_rice09@...> wrote:
>
> > As a rule, I avoid dotting adjectives, even if they are the possessive of an unambiguously dotted noun.
>
> Sensible.
>
> > My use of Foot instead of Ooze at the end of "into" is consistent with the Manual where unabbreviated "to" is spelled with Foot.
>
> I'm looking at that page (11) now, where a few paragraphs prior, "two" is spelled as if it's pronounced [tu]. Joy. Guess "too", "to", and "two" aren't all homophones in Readland.
>
> > I think that Read meant for it to be used in a similar way to final It when a vowel tends to be pronounced as a high-central vowel /ɨ/ and is not stressed. What hampered Read was that phonetic manuals of the time tended not to count /ɨ/ as a vowel that existed in English. This also explains the rule to omit writing a vowel between similar sounds when writing some past participles and plurals.
>
> Ah, OK.
>
> > On a similar note, it shows that syllabic consonants were also not well understood in Read's day. If I were to reform QS in any way, I would add a letter for /ɨ/ along with distinct letters for syllabic L, M and N.
>
> Now that I've been made aware of [1] and its use in English, I'm starting to see the utility of adding it.
>
> How would syllabic L, M, and N help anyone read or write, though?
>
